code: @Manual{,   title = {psycheval: A psychological evaluation toolkit},   author = {W. Joel Schneider},   year = {2021},   note = {R package version 0.1.0},   url = {https://github.com/wjschne/psycheval}, }

title: A psychological evaluation toolkit
text: psycheval package set functions can useful psychological evaluations. accompanies Individual Psychometrics online textbook.

title: A psychological evaluation toolkit
text: can install development version psycheval like :

what: Convert a variable to standard scores
title: A psychological evaluation toolkit
text: Suppose scaled score 12 (μ = 10, σ = 3) want convert standard score (μ = 100, σ = 15). convert z-score (μ = 0, σ = 1): convert T-score (μ = 50, σ = 10):
code: library(psycheval) x2standard(12, mu_x = 10, sigma_x = 3) #> [1] 110 x2standard(12,            mu_x = 10, sigma_x = 3,            mu_new = 0, sigma_new = 1) #> [1] 0.67 x2standard(12,            mu_x = 10, sigma_x = 3,            mu_new = 50, sigma_new = 10) #> [1] 57

what: Computes covariances of composite scores given a covariance matrix and a weight matrix — composite_covariance
title: Computes covariances of composite scores given a covariance matrix and a weight matrix — composite_covariance
text: Computes covariances composite scores given covariance matrix weight matrix

title: Computes covariances of composite scores given a covariance matrix and a weight matrix — composite_covariance
Computes covariances of composite scores given a covariance matrix and a weight matrix — composite_covariance
text: Sigma Covariance matrix w Weight matrix. Must number rows R correlation TRUE, return correlations instead covariances

title: Computes covariances of composite scores given a covariance matrix and a weight matrix — composite_covariance
code: # Create covariance matrix Sigma <- matrix(0.6, nrow = 5, ncol = 5) diag(Sigma) <- 1 # Create weight matrix w <- matrix(0, nrow = 5, ncol = 2) w[1:2,1] <- 1 w[3:5,2] <- 1 w #>      [,1] [,2] #> [1,]    1    0 #> [2,]    1    0 #> [3,]    0    1 #> [4,]    0    1 #> [5,]    0    1 # covariance matrix of weighted sums composite_covariance(Sigma, w) #>      [,1] [,2] #> [1,]  3.2  3.6 #> [2,]  3.6  6.6

what: General a multivariate confidence interval for a set of scores — multivariate_ci
title: General a multivariate confidence interval for a set of scores — multivariate_ci
text: General multivariate confidence interval set scores

title: General a multivariate confidence interval for a set of scores — multivariate_ci
code: multivariate_ci(x, rxx, mu, sigma, ci = 0.95, v_names = names(x))

title: General a multivariate confidence interval for a set of scores — multivariate_ci
text: x vector scores rxx vector reliability coefficients mu vector means sigma covariance matrix ci confidence level v_names vector names

title: General a multivariate confidence interval for a set of scores — multivariate_ci
General a multivariate confidence interval for a set of scores — multivariate_ci
code: x_wisc <- c(   vci = 130,   vsi = 130,   fri = 70,   wmi = 130,   psi = 130 ) rxx_wisc <- c(   vci = .92,   vsi = .92,   fri = .93,   wmi = .92,   psi = .88   ) R_wisc <- ("   index  vci   vsi   fri   wmi   psi   vci    1.00  0.59  0.59  0.53  0.30   vsi    0.59  1.00  0.62  0.50  0.36   fri    0.59  0.62  1.00  0.53  0.31   wmi    0.53  0.50  0.53  1.00  0.36   psi    0.30  0.36  0.31  0.36  1.00") |>     readr::read_tsv() |>     tibble::column_to_rownames("index") |>     as.matrix() #> Rows: 5 Columns: 6 #> -- Column specification -------------------------------------------------------- #> Delimiter: "\t" #> chr (1): index #> dbl (5): vci, vsi, fri, wmi, psi #>  #> i Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data. #> i Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.  multivariate_ci(    x = x_wisc,    rxx = rxx_wisc,    mu = rep(100, 5),    sigma = R_wisc * 225  ) #>     score   x  rxx mu_univariate see_univariate mu_multivariate #> vci   vci 130 0.92         127.6       4.069398       126.69804 #> vsi   vsi 130 0.92         127.6       4.069398       126.11601 #> fri   fri  70 0.93          72.1       3.827205        77.64056 #> wmi   wmi 130 0.92         127.6       4.069398       127.29155 #> psi   psi 130 0.88         126.4       4.874423       127.38539 #>     see_multivariate upper_univariate lower_univariate upper_multivariate #> vci         3.911922        135.57587        119.62413          134.36526 #> vsi         3.896561        135.57587        119.62413          133.75313 #> fri         3.685405         79.60118         64.59882           84.86382 #> wmi         3.953840        135.57587        119.62413          135.04093 #> psi         4.803025        135.95369        116.84631          136.79915 #>     lower_multivariate #> vci           119.0308 #> vsi           118.4789 #> fri            70.4173 #> wmi           119.5422 #> psi           117.9716

what: Convert x to a standard score — x2standard
title: Convert x to a standard score — x2standard
Convert x to a standard score — x2standard
code: x2standard(   x,   mu_x = mean(x, na.rm = T),   sigma_x = stats::sd(x, na.rm = T),   mu_new = 100,   sigma_new = 15,   digits = ifelse(sigma_new == 1, 2, 0) )

title: Convert x to a standard score — x2standard
text: x numeric vector mu_x mean current scores sigma_x standard deviation current scores mu_new mean new scores sigma_new standard deviation new scores digits rounding digits

title: Convert x to a standard score — x2standard
Convert x to a standard score — x2standard
